responses.topic: Generative AI Use Cases and Timeline
responses.content: Generative AI is an exciting area with two main themes for this year: efficiency and new product areas. We're integrating large language models and diffusion models to generate images, videos, avatars, and 3D assets across our products. These technologies will empower creators to be more productive and creative. We'll be launching various generative AI features this year and sharing updates on their performance. Scaling these technologies efficiently is a key challenge, but we anticipate significant use cases emerging as we overcome these hurdles.

Our approach with Reels mirrors our philosophy of prioritizing user engagement before monetization. As Reels scales to hundreds of millions of users, we'll focus on ramping up monetization. Currently, Reels is a $3 billion run rate but is still a $500 million revenue headwind. We expect to turn this into a revenue tailwind within the next 12 to 18 months by improving monetization efficiency. Additionally, our AI-driven discovery engine enhances engagement by providing more relevant content across Reels, Stories, and Feed, contributing to overall platform health.

We've undergone a phase change where rapid growth has slowed, necessitating a greater focus on efficiency. This involves reducing management layers and improving operational workflows, enabling us to execute more effectively and attract top talent. Our investments in the metaverse through Reality Labs continue, but we balance these with initiatives that drive immediate business growth and profitability. Maintaining a disciplined approach to expenses while investing in future technologies is crucial for our long-term success.

Generative AI is integral to our product development strategy, enhancing user experiences and creating new opportunities for content creation. By leveraging AI, we're able to offer more personalized and engaging content, which in turn drives higher user engagement and satisfaction. This technology also opens up new avenues for advertisers to create dynamic and interactive ads, further strengthening our advertising ecosystem.

AI plays a crucial role in our content moderation efforts. We release a community standards enforcement report every quarter, demonstrating that over 90% of actionable content is identified by AI before user reports. Continuous advancements in AI and machine learning are enabling us to maintain a safe and positive environment for our users while scaling our content moderation capabilities.

responses.topic: New Data Center Architecture and Capital Efficiency
responses.content: We're shifting our data centers to a new architecture that supports both AI and non-AI workloads more efficiently. This new design is cheaper and faster to build, providing us with greater flexibility to scale based on demand. Our phased approach allows us to build base plans with less initial capacity and scale up quickly as needed. This shift is expected to reduce long-term capital intensity and improve overall cash flow by lowering CapEx as a percentage of revenue.

Our 2023 operating expense (OpEx) guidance includes an estimated $2 billion in one-time charges related to office facilities consolidation as we rationalize our real estate footprint. Over half of the OpEx growth in 2023 is driven by headcount-related costs from employees hired in 2022, primarily in technical and senior roles. We expect headcount to be roughly flat by the end of 2023. On the cost of revenue side, growth will accelerate due to increased depreciation from prior CapEx investments and Reality Labs' next-generation Quest headset launch.

Our 2023 CapEx is projected to be between $34 billion and $39 billion, driven primarily by investments in AI and machine learning. These investments are enabling enhancements in our recommendation systems, ad targeting, and overall user engagement. We've observed a 15% watch time gain for Facebook Reels from a single AI advancement and anticipate further improvements. The ROI from these AI investments will determine our future CapEx spending. If we continue to see strong engagement and revenue gains, we will maintain or increase our investment levels.

In Q4, we continued to test shop ads in the U.S. and observed increased performance by directing consumers to points of purchase. The shop ads beta currently has a revenue run rate in the hundreds of millions of dollars, showing triple-digit growth in both revenue and adoption. We expect this growth to normalize to lower levels in 2023, with shop ads contributing significantly to our revenue streams as they scale.

Regarding the EU Digital Markets Act (DMA) and other regulatory issues, we believe our current approach to data usage and ad targeting is GDPR compliant. We are actively appealing the rulings that challenge our practices and are committed to working closely with regulators to resolve these issues. We do not anticipate these decisions affecting our ability to provide personalized advertising in the EU, allowing advertisers to continue leveraging our platforms effectively.

The primary components of the reduction in our 2023 expense outlook are slower payroll growth due to a broad hiring freeze and reduced headcount growth, slower growth in cost of revenue driven by extending the useful lives of non-AI servers, and lower office facilities consolidation charges. These adjustments allow us to better align our expenses with the current macroeconomic environment and maintain financial discipline.

We are very pleased with the engagement trends we're observing. Aggregate time spent on Instagram and Facebook is up year-over-year both in the U.S. and globally. Reels continues to add incremental time spent without significantly cannibalizing other surfaces like Feed and Stories. This positive trend indicates the durability and relevance of our platforms in our oldest market.

Reels currently operates at a $3 billion revenue run rate but is still a $500 million revenue headwind this quarter. We expect to turn Reels into a revenue tailwind within the next 12 to 18 months as we enhance monetization efficiency. Our strategy focuses on scaling Reels engagement and optimizing ad placements to drive profitable growth.

The impact of Apple's ATT changes is primarily due to lapping the rollout period. While we see some benefits from lapping the rollout, macroeconomic headwinds continue to pose challenges. Our efforts to mitigate ATT impacts include enhancing our ad tools, investing in AI-driven targeting, and promoting on-site conversions through products like click-to-messaging ads. These initiatives are helping us offset some of the revenue declines caused by ATT.

responses.topic: Capital Expenditures (CapEx) and Data Center Efficiency
responses.content: Our shift to a new data center architecture is expected to reduce long-term capital intensity by making our operations more efficient. This new architecture supports both AI and non-AI workloads more effectively and is cheaper and faster to build. By adopting a phased approach, we can scale capacity based on demand without significant upfront capital outlays, improving our cash flow and reducing CapEx as a percentage of revenue over time.

Reels is contributing positively to overall engagement on our platforms. We are actively working on closing the monetization gap between Reels and other surfaces like Feed and Stories. With ongoing improvements in ad targeting and content recommendations driven by AI, we anticipate that Reels will soon become a revenue driver rather than a headwind.

Investments in the metaverse through Reality Labs remain a long-term commitment. We are increasing our investment in this area while maintaining discipline across the entire operating posture of the company. These investments are essential for positioning Meta as a leader in the next generation of social interaction and digital economy.

We continue to rebuild meaningful elements of our ad tech to improve performance and measurement. Our focus includes growing on-site conversions with products like lead ads and click-to-messaging ads. Investments in AI and machine learning are enhancing our measurement, targeting, and delivery capabilities. Early examples, such as Advantage+ Shopping, have shown promising results with a 32% increase in return on ad spend for advertisers. We are also collaborating with the industry to develop privacy-enhancing technologies to support advertisers in this new environment.

Our AI and ML investments are central to maintaining and enhancing our competitive advantage. By improving our recommendation systems and ad targeting, we can offer advertisers more effective and measurable solutions. Products like Advantage+ Shopping exemplify how AI-driven tools can deliver significant ROI for advertisers, reinforcing our position as a leader in the digital advertising space.

Click-to-Messaging ads are one of our fastest-growing ad formats, now a $10 billion revenue run rate. These ads are bringing incremental demand to our platform, with over 40% of our advertisers using Reels across our apps. Advertisers are seeing significant ROI improvements, such as lower cost per acquisition and higher conversion rates. Examples include businesses achieving higher qualified leads and lower costs per lead compared to traditional ad formats.

In Q4, we continued to test shop ads in the U.S. and observed increased performance by directing consumers to points of purchase. The shop ads beta currently has a revenue run rate in the hundreds of millions of dollars, showing triple-digit growth in both revenue and adoption. We expect this growth to normalize to lower levels in 2023, with shop ads contributing significantly to our revenue streams as they scale.

questions: Mark, can you delve deeper into how you think about your blue-sky potential user and advertiser use cases of generative AI? And how do you foresee the timeline for some glimpses of those on the platform?

Susan, can you provide more color on the new data center architecture and how we should think about the long-term capital intensity of the business, whether it’s CapEx per minute, CapEx per DAU? How big of a long-term benefit could this change be to the overall cash flow?
Mark, you mentioned expecting revenue growth in 2023. Can you share the key drivers behind that and how much is macro-driven versus initiatives you're working on?
Susan, regarding the operating expense guidance for 2023, how much conservatism is baked in, and how flexible is the guidance to adjust expenses based on the core business health?
Mark, how do you plan to balance growing engagement with short-form video like Reels against driving higher levels of monetization for this product?
Can you provide color on how advertiser conversations are evolving around short-form video and the adoption of Canvas for delivering a mix of brand and direct response messages?
Can you quantify the current gap between engagement and monetization for short-form video, and how you expect this gap to close over the next couple of years?
Mark, can you discuss the added signals Meta is gaining from the AI discovery engine to produce more relevant content across Reels, Stories, Feed, and Messenger?
Should we continue to expect accelerating losses at Reality Labs in 2023, and do you anticipate Reality Labs reaching peak losses this year?
Can you comment on the scaling of shop ads this year and how they are expected to contribute to revenue?
Are you still facing headwinds from IDFA or ATT in the first quarter, or have you moved past that?
Looking ahead, are there any developments with Android or the EU Digital Markets Act that we should be aware of?

Susan, can you speak to the relationship between revenue growth and OpEx and CapEx growth over time? Are you moving towards aligning these more closely, or is the business still in an investment mode leading to margin compression beyond 2023?
Mark, can you provide an update on the health of the broader digital ad space, especially for SMBs and direct response, and whether you are becoming more bullish or remain cautious?
Mark, how are the added signals from the AI discovery engine enhancing content relevance across Reels, Stories, Feed, and Messenger?
Susan, can you elaborate on the long-term capital efficiency gains from the new data center architecture and its impact on cash flow?
Why don’t you feel these new investments are experimental and believe they will pay off?
How does the Reels transition compare to proven bets on the core business?
Can you confirm if MAUs will be down sequentially in Q1?
Can you quantify how much TikTok is impacting Facebook?
Regarding ad tools, how much priority is being given to developing a new probabilistic ad attribution and targeting model, and is it a major investment priority or are you focusing on other areas?
Can you provide an update on the progress of your metaverse strategy, including product rollout and engagement with platforms like Horizon World, and whether the opportunity is evolving as expected?
